metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. K. Y. Pilliah & Sons

facts.text: Respondents, Messrs. K. Y. Pilliah Sons, declared Rs. 18,679 as income from business for assessment year 1951-52.
In assessee's cloth business, gross profits from disclosed turnover worked out at 3.8% while other merchants in same locality had 6 to 7%.
Relevant vouchers for purchases not produced; purchases unproved beyond book entries.
Assessee sold cloth in name of Bhuvaneswariah (son of principal partner K. Y. Pilliah) and Veerabhadrappa (accountant).
Assessee claimed net turnover Rs. 9,42,524-8-9; ITO rejected and estimated turnover at Rs. 12 lakhs with gross profit at 6.5%, adding Rs. 41,142 to income.
Two credit entries totalling Rs. 7,000 in name of Sampangappa in November and December 1950.
Sampangappa examined by ITO; admitted not in position to advance any amount at relevant time.
ITO treated Rs. 7,000 as income from undisclosed sources.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order.
In Tribunal appeal, assessee contended add only Rs. 1,05,031-12-0 from proved benami transactions; Rs. 7,000 attributable to secreted profits.
Tribunal found assessee suppressed not only sales but corresponding purchases; sales not entered to save sales tax (stated to ITO, not persisted before Tribunal).
Tribunal upheld estimate of Rs. 12 lakhs turnover as suppression of over Rs. 1 lakh proved; rejected lower GP rate and Rs. 7,000 as secreted profits.
High Court called statement of case under s.66(2) on two questions.
High Court held Tribunal influenced by irrelevant considerations (suppression habit, sales tax evasion); no application of mind to Rs. 7,000; answered in favour of assessee.
Transactions with Hameedia Stores and T. Venkataram not entered, extent unascertainable.

legal_issues.text: Whether the estimate of the income of the assessee confirmed by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rests upon irrelevant considerations and the estimate is not made in accordance with law?

Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was justified in sustaining both the additions of Rs. 41,142 as income from business and Rs. 7,000 as cash credits and whether such addition does not result in double taxation?

petitioner_arguments.text: Books unreliable due to unproved purchases, benami sales in names of son and accountant not entered; turnover understated, GP rate low vs others (6-7%); estimate of Rs.12 lakhs at 6.5% justified; power to estimate exercised judicially.
Rs.7,000 cash credits unexplained; Sampangappa unable to lend; not secreted profits as no evidence; Tribunal can affirm AAC without repeating reasons.

respondent_arguments.text: Add only Rs.1,05,031-12-0 from proved benami transactions; turnover estimate of Rs.12 lakhs excessive; GP rate should not be 6.5%; Rs.7,000 attributable to secreted profits already taxed.
Tribunal influenced by irrelevant considerations like suppression habit and sales tax evasion.

court_reasoning.text: True income cannot be deduced from books; conceded by assessee. Transactions outside books proved; estimate of turnover Rs.12 lakhs and GP 6.5% reasonable based on comparable merchants; not arbitrary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suppression of sales over Rs.1 lakh proved; other unascertainable transactions exist.

court_reasoning.text: Reasons of Tribunal not irrelevant; power to estimate exercised judicially on relevant materials.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No explanation for low GP rate.

court_reasoning.text: Rs.41,142 is additional profit on estimated turnover; no other outgoings claimed.
Tribunal not required to repeat AAC reasons if fully agrees; Sampangappa unable to advance; no evidence for secreted profits; no double taxation.

holdings.text: Estimate of income rests on relevant considerations and made in accordance with law.
Tribunal justified in sustaining additions of Rs.41,142 and Rs.7,000; no double taxation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court called for statement of case on reference questions.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; both questions answered in negative for first (no irrelevant considerations, estimate per law) and affirmative for first part of second (justified additions), second part not determined.
outcome.relief_granted: Reversal of High Court judgment in favour of assessee.

key_quotes.text: The power must of course be exercised not arbitrarily, but judicially in the light of relevant materials.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines standard for ITO's estimation power.

key_quotes.text: Prima facie, these were findings on questions of fact, and no question of law arose out of the order of the Tribunal.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: in failing to record reasons, when the Appellate Tribunal fully agrees with the view expressed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner... it does not act illegally.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Tribunal need not repeat lower reasons if agrees.
